nl.naturalis.nda.elasticsearch.load

Class ETLStatistics

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.nda.elasticsearch.load.ETLStatistics

  • public class ETLStatistics
extends Object
    A Java bean maintaining a set of running totals for an ETL program. A statistics object is passed around by the ETL components of an import program so each can update the counter(s) relevant to its job. A distinction is made between record-level statistics and object-level statistics. This is because one record in a data source may yield multiple objects (i.e. ElasticSearch documents). For example one record in a Brahms CSV dump may contain multiple images. Thus the number of records processed is not necessarily equal to the number of documents indexed, even if there were no validation errors. For this type of data sources an attempt is made to distinguish between record-level validation errors and object-level validation errors, but the distinction is sometimes somewhat arbitrary.

    For data sources with a one-to-one relationship between records and objects (each record produces one object/document), the distinction between record-level statistics and object-level statistics is totally arbitrary. Current implementations of Transformer only use the recordsRejected and recordsSkipped counters to report on invalid c.q. skipped data while leaving the objectsRejected and objectsSkipped counters alone.

    The following rules apply:

     recordsSkipped + recordsRejected + recordsAccepted == recordsProcessed
 objectsSkipped + objectsRejected + objectsAccepted == objectsProcessed
 documentsRejected + documentsIndexed == objectsAccepted

    For data sources where each record produces just one document an extra rule applies:

      objectsSkipped + objectsRejected + objectsAccepted == recordsAccepted

    Nested Documents

    Sometimes the records in a data source, or the objects extracted from them, are not processed to create new documents. Instead they are only used to enrich existing documents. For example, the vernacular names in the vernacular.txt file of a DwC archive are not stored in a separate document type. Instead, they are nested within existing taxon documents. The same applies for synonyms, literature references and geological distribution data. In this case the number of indexed documents is virtually meaningless and has no relation with the number of valid (accepted) objects. If a data source provides 10 children for a particular parent document, the parent document could be re-indexed anywhere between 1 and 10 times during the course of the program, depending on how far apart the CSV/XML records containing the children were. If they all came one after another in the data source, they are added all at once to the parent document, resulting in just one index request for 10 child records. Thus, the following rule does not apply any longer:

     documentsRejected + documentsIndexed == objectsAccepted
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Field Detail

      • badInput

        public int badInput
        The number of times that the source data could not be parsed into a record. This counter is maintained by extractor components (e.g. CSV extractors). The badInput counter is useful when processing CSV files, where a raw line may not be parsable into a CSVRecord. It is not very useful when processing XML files, because these are parsed as a whole into a DOM tree, which is an all-or-nothing operation. Note that this counter does not contribute to the number of processed records. If we have bad input (e.g. a CSV record with too few fields), we by definition don't know if it was one, two, or whatever number of records (maybe the remaining fields came on the next line because of an un-escaped newline character). We only start counting records once we're passed the extraction phase.

      • recordsProcessed

        public int recordsProcessed
        The number of records processed by the import program. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects

      • recordsSkipped

        public int recordsSkipped
        The number of records that are not meant to be processed by the import program. For example, the taxa.txt file in a CoL DwC archive contains both taxa and synonyms. The taxon importer only cares about the taxa in that file while the synonym importer only cares about the synonyms in that file. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • recordsRejected

        public int recordsRejected
        The number of records that failed some validation. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • recordsAccepted

        public int recordsAccepted
        The number of successfully validated records. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • objectsProcessed

        public int objectsProcessed
        The number of objects processed by the import program. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • objectsSkipped

        public int objectsSkipped
        The number of objects that are not meant to be imported by the import program. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • objectsRejected

        public int objectsRejected
        The number of objects that failed some validation. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • objectsAccepted

        public int objectsAccepted
        The number of objects that passed validation. This counter is maintained by Transformer objects.

      • documentsRejected

        public int documentsRejected
        The number of objects that could not be indexed by ElasticSearch. This counter is maintained by loader objects.

      • documentsIndexed

        public int documentsIndexed
        The number of documents indexed by ElasticSearch. This counter is maintained by loader objects.

    • Method Detail

      • isOneToMany

        public boolean isOneToMany()
        Whether or not the data source being processed may yield multiple objects/documents per record.
        Returns:

      • setOneToMany

        public void setOneToMany(boolean oneToMany)
        Determines whether the data source being processed may yield multiple objects/documents per record. Specifying true or false results in slightly different output from logStatistics(). When false, both of the following rules apply: 
         objectsSkipped + objectsRejected + objectsAccepted == recordsAccepted
 objectsSkipped + objectsRejected + objectsAccepted == objectsProcessed
        Since the first rule is more insightful of the extract-transform-load process, that's the rule you will see in the output of logStatistics(). For one-to-many data sources (true), however, only the second rule is guaranteed to apply, so that's the rule you will see in the output. When nesting documents the oneToMany is ignored and the assumption will be that only second rule is guaranteed to apply.
        Parameters:
        oneToMany -

      • isNested

        public boolean isNested()
        Whether or not the records being processed are stored as nested documents.
        Returns:
        See Also:
        setNested(boolean)

      • setNested

        public void setNested(boolean nested)
        Determines whether the records being processed are stored as nested documents. Specifying true results in slightly different output when calling logStatistics(). When true, the following rule does not apply any longer: 
         documentsRejected + documentsIndexed == objectsAccepted
        Therefore, you will still be informed of the number of rejected and indexed documents, but you will not see them summed to yield the objectsAccepted statistic.
        Parameters:
        nested -

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets all counters to zero.
